00001 #include <mm/phys_mm.h>
00002 #include <mm/virt_mm.h>
00003 #include <debug/debug.h>
00004 #include <multiboot.h>
00005 #include <panic/panic.h>
00006 #include <types/memory.h>
00007 
00008 MEM_LOC used_mem_end = 0;
00009 
00010 MEM_LOC phys_mm_slock = PHYS_MM_STACK_ADDR;
00011 MEM_LOC phys_mm_smax = PHYS_MM_STACK_ADDR;
00012 
00013 extern uint32 paging_enabled;
00014 
00015 void init_phys_mm(MEM_LOC start) 
00016 {
00017         DEBUG_PRINT("Debug Message: Used memory end 0x%x\n", start);
00018 
00019         used_mem_end = (start + 0x1000) & ~(0xFFF); //This ensures that the used_mem_end address is on a page-aligned boundry (Which it has to be if I wish to identity map from 0 to used_mem_end)
00020 }
00021 
00022 MEM_LOC allocateKernelFrame() 
00023 {
00024         if (paging_enabled == 0) 
00025         {
00026                 used_mem_end += 4096; //Add 4096 bytes (4kb) to used_mem_end address
00027                 return used_mem_end - 4096; //Return the old address
00028                 //The reason why this works is that all memory up to used_mem_end is identity mapped when paging is enabled
00029                 //This meens that when paging is enabled the address will be mapped directly to the physical address (0x1000 will still access 0x1000 in memory for example) 
00030         } 
00031         else 
00032         {
00033 
00034                 //Paging is enabled     
00035                 if (phys_mm_slock == PHYS_MM_STACK_ADDR)
00036                 {
00037                         DEBUG_PRINT("Out of physical frames of memory (Allocate kernel frame)\n");
00038                         return 0; //Frame 0 should never be free
00039                 }
00040 
00041                 // Pop off the stack.
00042                 phys_mm_slock -= sizeof (uint32);
00043 
00044                 uint32 * stack = (uint32 *)phys_mm_slock;
00045 
00046                 return *stack;
00047         }
00048 }
00049 
00050 MEM_LOC allocateFrame() 
00051 {
00052         if (paging_enabled == 0) 
00053         {
00054                 used_mem_end += 4096; //Add 4096 bytes (4kb) to used_mem_end address
00055                 return used_mem_end - 4096; //Return the old address
00056                 //The reason why this works is that all memory up to used_mem_end is identity mapped when paging is enabled
00057                 //This meens that when paging is enabled the address will be mapped directly to the physical address (0x1000 will still access 0x1000 in memory for example) 
00058         } 
00059         else 
00060         {
00061 
00062                 //Paging is enabled     
00063                 if (phys_mm_slock == PHYS_MM_STACK_ADDR)
00064                 {
00065                         DEBUG_PRINT("Out of physical frames of memory (allocateFrame)\n");
00066                         return 0; //Frame 0 should never be free
00067                 }
00068 
00069                 // Pop off the stack.
00070                 phys_mm_slock -= sizeof (uint32);
00071 
00072                 uint32 * stack = (uint32 *)phys_mm_slock;
00073 
00074                 if (get_current_process() != 0)
00075                 {
00076                         used_list_add(get_current_process(), *stack);
00077                 }
00078 
00079                 return *stack;
00080         }
00081 }
00082 
00083 MEM_LOC allocateFrameForProcess(process_t* req_process) 
00084 {
00085         if (paging_enabled == 0) 
00086         {
00087                 used_mem_end += 4096; //Add 4096 bytes (4kb) to used_mem_end address
00088                 return used_mem_end - 4096; //Return the old address
00089                 //The reason why this works is that all memory up to used_mem_end is identity mapped when paging is enabled
00090                 //This meens that when paging is enabled the address will be mapped directly to the physical address (0x1000 will still access 0x1000 in memory for example) 
00091         } 
00092         else 
00093         {
00094 
00095                 //Paging is enabled     
00096                 if (phys_mm_slock == PHYS_MM_STACK_ADDR)
00097                 {
00098                         DEBUG_PRINT("Out of physical frames of memory (allocateFrameForProcess)\n");
00099                         return 0; //Frame 0 should never be free
00100                 }
00101 
00102                 // Pop off the stack.
00103                 phys_mm_slock -= sizeof (MEM_LOC);
00104 
00105                 MEM_LOC* stack = (MEM_LOC*)phys_mm_slock;
00106 
00107                 if (req_process != 0)
00108                 {
00109                         used_list_add(req_process, *stack);
00110                 }
00111 
00112                 return *stack;
00113         }
00114 }
00115 
00116 void freeFrame(MEM_LOC frame) 
00117 {
00118         if (paging_enabled == 0) 
00119         {
00120                 return; //If paging isn't enabled we are not going to be able to free a frame of virtual memory and the stacks location is virtual (Cannot be accessed without paging)  
00121         }       
00122 
00123         if (frame < used_mem_end + PAGE_SIZE) 
00124         {
00125                 return; //Anything under used_mem_end is identity mapped (Physical Address == Virtual Address) never remap it.
00126         }
00127 
00128         if (get_current_process() != 0)
00129         {
00130                 used_list_remove(get_current_process(), frame);
00131         }
00132 
00133         if (phys_mm_smax <= phys_mm_slock) //Run out of stack space *Shock Horror* Allocate this frame to the end of the stack (Giving another 4kb (4096 bytes) of stack space)
00134         {
00135             map ((POINTER) phys_mm_smax, (POINTER) frame, PAGE_PRESENT | PAGE_USER);
00136             phys_mm_smax += PAGE_SIZE;
00137         
00138         }
00139         else
00140         {
00141                 //We still have stack space left to pop to,
00142                 MEM_LOC* stack = ((POINTER)phys_mm_slock);
00143                 *stack = frame;
00144                 phys_mm_slock += sizeof(uint32);        
00145         }
00146 }
00147 
00148 //Does the initialization of the free pages using the memory map provided by the mboot header.
00149 void map_free_pages(struct multiboot * mboot_ptr) 
00150 {
00151 
00152   uint32 i = mboot_ptr->mmap_addr;
00153   uint32 dbiter = 0;
00154 
00155   while (i < mboot_ptr->mmap_addr + mboot_ptr->mmap_length)
00156   {
00157     mmap_entry_t *me = (mmap_entry_t*) i;
00158     
00159     // Does this entry specify usable RAM?
00160     if (me->type == 1)
00161     {
00162 
00163       uint32 j;
00164 
00165       // For every page in this entry, add to the free page stack.
00166       for (j = me->base_addr_low; j < me->base_addr_low+me->length_low; j += 0x1000)
00167       {
00168         freeFrame(j);
00169         dbiter++;
00170       }
00171 
00172     }
00173 
00174     // The multiboot specification is strange in this respect - the size member does not include "size" itself in its calculations,
00175     // so we must add sizeof a 32bit int
00176     i += me->size + sizeof (uint32);
00177   }
00178 
00179   DEBUG_PRINT("Debug Message: Map Free Pages finished with 0x%x pages of free memory (PAGE SIZE: 0x%x)\n", dbiter, PAGE_SIZE);
00180 }
00181 
00182 extern void asm_copy_frame(uint32 src, uint32 dest);
00183 MEM_LOC calculate_free_frames()
00184 {
00185         return ((phys_mm_slock - PHYS_MM_STACK_ADDR) / sizeof(MEM_LOC));
00186 }
